message_1: What is the major product of the reaction between 2-methyl-2-pentanol and conc. HBr?
message_2:
The major product of the reaction between 2-methyl-2-pentanol and concentrated HBr is 2-bromo-2-methylpentane.

The reaction proceeds via an S_N1 mechanism. In the first step, the hydroxyl group of 2-methyl-2-pentanol is protonated by HBr, forming a good leaving group (water). The protonated alcohol then undergoes a unimolecular nucleophilic substitution (S_N1) reaction, in which the water molecule leaves, forming a carbocation intermediate. The carbocation is stabilized by the two methyl groups adjacent to the positively charged carbon atom. Finally, the bromide ion (Br-) from the HBr attacks the carbocation, resulting in the formation of 2-bromo-2-methylpentane as the major product.
